G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $7,500 in medical expenses and $2,000 in lost wages, exclusive of pain and suffering and other damages, and is within the jurisdictional limits of the Lynn District Court. See G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in the Lynn District Court because the events giving rise to this action occurred at the Premises located at 123 Maple Street in Lynn, Essex County, Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant, as landlord and property manager, had a nondelegable duty to maintain the common areas of the Premises, including smoke detectors and related life‑safety systems, in a reasonably safe condition and in compliance with Massachusetts law. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: Defendant, as landlord and property manager, had a nondelegable duty to maintain the common areas of the Premises, including smoke detectors and related life‑safety systems, in a reasonably safe condition and in compliance with Massachusetts law. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: Young v. Garwacki holds that landlords owe a general duty of reasonable care in negligence to tenants’ guests for defects on the demised premises and discusses statutory duties under G.L. c. 186, including § 19 and § 15. It does not, however, characterize the landlord’s duty as “nondelegable,” nor does it specifically address smoke detectors or life‑safety systems, and it does not construe G.L. c. 186, § 14 at all. Thus, while it supports a broad negligence duty, it does not support the specific nondelegable-duty proposition stated, nor the reliance on § 14 for that point.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk. … Our statutes do not support limiting a landlord’s negligence liability to areas under his control. General Laws c. 186, § 19, requires most landlords to exercise reasonable care to correct an unsafe condition….”

105 CMR 410.482.proposition: Massachusetts regulations, including but not limited to 105 CMR 410.482 and related provisions of the State Sanitary Code, require landlords to provide and maintain smoke detection and fire warning systems in residential rental premises.

780 CMR (State Building Code).proposition: The Massachusetts State Building Code and State Fire Code likewise require properly functioning smoke detection in common areas of multi‑unit residential buildings, including common halls that serve as egress routes for tenants. See, e.g., 780 CMR (State Building Code) and 527 CMR (State Fire Code).

527 CMR (State Fire Code).proposition: The Massachusetts State Building Code and State Fire Code likewise require properly functioning smoke detection in common areas of multi‑unit residential buildings, including common halls that serve as egress routes for tenants. See, e.g., 780 CMR (State Building Code) and 527 CMR (State Fire Code).

G.L. c. 143.proposition: Defendant’s duty arises from the common law of negligence, the implied warranty of habitability, and statutory and regulatory obligations, including but not limited to: a. G.L. c. 186, § 14 (requiring landlords to maintain premises in compliance with law and not to interfere with quiet enjoyment); b. G.L. c. 143 and related provisions of the State Building Code (780 CMR), requiring appropriate fire and life‑safety equipment; and c. 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary Code, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation), including requirements for smoke detectors and fire warning systems.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: Defendant’s duty arises from the common law of negligence, the implied warranty of habitability, and statutory and regulatory obligations, including but not limited to: a. G.L. c. 186, § 14 (requiring landlords to maintain premises in compliance with law and not to interfere with quiet enjoyment); b. G.L. c. 143 and related provisions of the State Building Code (780 CMR), requiring appropriate fire and life‑safety equipment; and c. 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary Code, Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation), including requirements for smoke detectors and fire warning systems.

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82\u20.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landlords must exercise reasonable care to prevent defective conditions in areas under their control that create a risk of harm to tenants, including dangers from fire and smoke. See Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82–83 (1977); King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 660–61 (1977).
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in maintaining property under her control to all lawful visitors, including tenants’ visitors, and applies that duty to the condition and lighting of a common stairway. The discussion focuses on safe maintenance of common passageways and specifically on the adequacy of lighting, thereby encompassing risks such as those posed by darkness that could analogously include fire and smoke hazards in areas under the landlord’s control.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82\u20.relevant_excerpt: “The landowner’s duty of reasonable care in maintaining property he controls extends to all lawful visitors on his premises, including the lawful visitors of his tenants… The amount of light cast on the stairway in question is relevant to the issue of negligence because this factor assists the jury in deciding whether Massios took reasonable measures to ensure the safe passage of visitors on her stairway after dark… In summary, we hold that Massios owed Lindsey a duty to use reasonable care in the maintenance of the premises on which Lindsey was injured.”

King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.raw_text: King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 660–61 (1977)
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landlords must exercise reasonable care to prevent defective conditions in areas under their control that create a risk of harm to tenants, including dangers from fire and smoke. See Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82–83 (1977); King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 660–61 (1977).
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that a landlord owes a general, continuing duty of reasonable care to tenants regarding common areas under the landlord’s control, displacing the older, more limited Massachusetts rule. While the facts involve a defective stairway rather than fire or smoke, the legal rule clearly applies to any dangerous condition in such common areas, and thus supports the broader proposition that landlords must exercise reasonable care to prevent defective conditions that create risks of harm to tenants.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.relevant_excerpt: “We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ in kind from that owed by the landlord to the tenant’s visitors… We add here the several practical considerations… that lead us to favor the application to them of the rule which now prevails in this country… ‘A landlord… is subject to liability to his tenant and others lawfully upon the leased property… for physical harm caused by a dangerous condition… if the landlord by the exercise of reasonable care could have… discovered the condition… and… made the condition safe.’”

Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828, 832 (199.proposition: Defendant also had a duty, once notified of a defective smoke detector or similar hazard, to take reasonable steps within a reasonable time to repair, replace, or otherwise correct the condition. See Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828, 832 (1997).
Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828, 832 (199.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts a duty, once notified of a defective smoke detector or similar hazard, to take reasonable steps within a reasonable time to correct the condition. Lyon v. Morphew does not involve smoke detectors or analogous latent hazards; it concerns personal liability of hospital employees for failure to provide or replace a roof safety railing and for not directing an independent roofing contractor to install fall protection. The court explicitly finds no common-law or statutory duty to provide or maintain such safety devices on the roof and rejects imposing liability on these employees, so the case does not establish the claimed duty and in fact points the other way.
Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828, 832 (199.relevant_excerpt: “From the evidence viewed in a light most favorable to the plaintiff, it could be inferred that they played a role in determining whether the hospital should replace the railing or install an alternative safety device; however, they had no common law or statutory duty to do either. … We have never recognized a common law duty of building owners to place or maintain fall protection safety devices on roofs.”

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Massachusetts law holds that violation of a safety statute or regulation designed to protect tenants may be evidence of negligence. See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990); Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841–42 (1976).
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the evidentiary effect of violating a safety-related statute (G.L. c. 138, § 69), but it does so in the context of alcohol-service liability to the general public, not in the landlord–tenant context. It states the general Massachusetts rule that statutory violations are only “some evidence” of negligence and do not constitute negligence per se, but it does not mention tenants or statutes/regulations designed specifically to protect tenants. Thus Bennett supports the general evidentiary principle about statutory violations, but not the more specific tenant-focused proposition as framed.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841\u2.proposition: Massachusetts law holds that violation of a safety statute or regulation designed to protect tenants may be evidence of negligence. See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990); Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841–42 (1976).
Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841\u2.support_reasoning: The court squarely states the Massachusetts rule that violation of a safety statute or ordinance is evidence of negligence, and applies that rule to a municipal building code provision regulating the configuration of common exit stairs in a residential building. The opinion explains that the excluded building code section was intended to prevent falls on stairs and that its violation could be considered by the jury as evidence of the landlord’s negligence toward the tenant. This directly supports the proposition that, under Massachusetts law, violation of a safety measure designed to protect tenants may be evidence of negligence.
Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841\u2.relevant_excerpt: “With the benefit of the excluded portion of § 6.08 the jury could have found that there was a violation of the building code which contributed to the plaintiff’s injury. ‘The general rule in Massachusetts is that violation of the safety statute or ordinance does not in itself give rise to a cause of action but is evidence of negligence.’ … [I]t ‘…is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent.’”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s conduct in ignoring Plaintiff’s repeated complaints and failing to “take care of” the problem within a reasonable time constitutes a further breach of its duty of reasonable care. See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 379 (2010) (reasonable care standard applies to property owners as to hazards they know or should know about).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: Papadopoulos does stand for the general rule that property owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care as to hazards they know or should know about, including snow and ice. However, it does not address or discuss the specific issue of a defendant ignoring repeated complaints from a plaintiff or characterize such inaction as a "further breach" of duty. The cited page articulates the general reasonable care standard, not the more specific proposition about ignoring repeated complaints and failing to act within a reasonable time.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to "act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk." ... If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property ... the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.raw_text: Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990)
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about Plaintiff’s injuries and damages and was a proximate cause of those injuries under Massachusetts law. See Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law on causation); Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320–21 (2002).
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly articulates Massachusetts’ proximate cause standard as requiring foreseeability plus that the defendant’s negligence be both a but‑for cause and a substantial factor in bringing about the loss. The court then applies that standard in evaluating whether Massport’s negligence proximately caused the plaintiffs’ alleged reputation and economic injuries. Thus, it is proper authority for the general Massachusetts-law proposition that a defendant’s negligence must be a substantial factor and a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries.
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.relevant_excerpt: Under Massachusetts law, proximate cause requires a showing by the plaintiff, first, that the loss was a foreseeable consequence of the defendant's negligence, second, that the defendant's negligence was a but-for cause of the loss, and third, that the defendant's negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about the loss. The last two elements relate to the concept of actual causation, or causation-in-fact.

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about Plaintiff’s injuries and damages and was a proximate cause of those injuries under Massachusetts law. See Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law on causation); Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320–21 (2002).
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: Kent does discuss proximate cause under Massachusetts negligence law and uses a foreseeability-based formulation, but the holding is that the defendant’s (Commonwealth’s) negligence was not the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries as a matter of law due to a superseding cause. The opinion does not stand for the general affirmative proposition that a defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injuries; instead, it is an example where proximate cause was found lacking. Using Kent to show that negligence was a substantial factor and proximate cause mischaracterizes the case’s holding.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935). Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60H.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and compensation for pain and suffering. See G.L. c. 231, § 60H; Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198, 217 (1999); Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 549–50 (1982).

Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and compensation for pain and suffering. See G.L. c. 231, § 60H; Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198, 217 (1999); Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 549–50 (1982).
Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns product liability, evidentiary issues, wrongful death, comparative negligence, and nunc pro tunc judgment; it does not discuss the general scope or categories of recoverable tort damages. The cited page (430 Mass. at 217) addresses prejudgment interest and indemnity, not a statement that plaintiffs are entitled to recover all proximate damages including medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and pain and suffering. Thus, Santos is not authority for the broad damages proposition stated.

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and compensation for pain and suffering. See G.L. c. 231, § 60H; Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198, 217 (1999); Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 549–50 (1982).
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.support_reasoning: Payton v. Abbott Labs is focused on whether Massachusetts recognizes a cause of action for negligent infliction of emotional distress without physical harm, prenatal injury claims, wrongful-life-type arguments, and market-share liability for DES manufacturers. It does not discuss the general measure or categories of damages recoverable in a standard negligence action (medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering), nor does it interpret G.L. c. 231, § 60H. Therefore it does not provide authority for the broad damages proposition for which it is cited.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.relevant_excerpt: "In summary, we hold that a plaintiff who alleges that she suffered injury in utero as a result of her mother's ingestion of a drug and that, but for the defendant's negligence, her mother would not have ingested that drug, has stated a claim upon which relief can be granted under Massachusetts law."

G.L. c. 93A.proposition: To the extent any of Defendant’s conduct is found to constitute a willful or knowing violation of statutory obligations relating to the condition of the Premises, Plaintiff reserves all rights to seek any enhanced or multiple damages available under applicable statutes, including G.L. c. 93A and G.L. c. 186, § 14, although the present Complaint sounds solely in common‑law negligence.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B..proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including under G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38..proposition: Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.
